title: 106_s3254
content: The Act may be cited as the "East Timor Transition to Independence Act of 2000". The East Timorese people voted for independence from Indonesia in 1999, leading to a violent campaign by anti-independence militias supported by the Indonesian military. This resulted in mass displacement, destruction of infrastructure, and collapse of government services. The International Force for East Timor restored order in September 1999. The United Nations Transitional Administration for East Timor (UNTAET) took over administration of East Timor in 1999 to establish a new democratic government and maintain security. East Timor is anticipated to become independent by late 2001, despite being one of the poorest places in Asia with high poverty, low literacy rates, and unemployment. The World Bank and United Nations have estimated the country's dire economic situation. The World Bank and the United Nations estimate that East Timor will need $300 million in development assistance over the next three years to meet its basic development needs. The Sense of Congress supports East Timor with $300 million in development assistance over the next three years. The Sense of Congress supports facilitating East Timor's transition to independence, forming a democracy, aiding economic recovery, and enhancing security. It also calls for establishing diplomatic relations and a fully functioning US mission in East Timor upon independence, as well as supporting trade and investment relationships. The Sense of Congress supports efforts by the United Nations and East Timor to ensure justice and accountability for past atrocities through investigations, developing East Timor's judicial system with technical assistance, and possibly establishing an international tribunal. It also supports observer status for an official delegation from East Timor to participate in APEC deliberations. SEC. 4. BILATERAL ASSISTANCE. The President, through the Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development, is authorized to support civil society, independent news media, job creation, economic development, reconciliation, conflict resolution, repatriation of refugees, and political party development in East Timor. Support for political party development, voter education, and voter registration in East Timor is authorized with an appropriation of $25,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2001 to 2003. The funds will remain available until expended. The President shall instruct the US executive director at international financial institutions to support economic and democratic development in East Timor. Peace Corps assistance is also authorized. SEC. 6 authorizes the Peace Corps to provide training and assistance in East Timor, including immediate aid through the Crisis Corps. $2,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year 2001-2003. The President should negotiate with UNTAET, the National Council of East Timor, and the government of East Timor to expand US investment in East Timor through OPIC agreements. The Trade and Development Agency Director is authorized to carry out projects in East Timor under the Foreign Assistance Act. The Export-Import Bank of the United States is authorized to expand its activities in connection with exports to East Timor. $1,000,000 is authorized to be appropriated for each fiscal year from 2001 to 2003 for this purpose. Amounts appropriated will remain available until expended. SEC. 8. GENERALIZED SYSTEM OF PREFERENCES. Congress encourages UNTAET and the National Council of East Timor to seek duty-free treatment under the Trade Act of 1974. The US is authorized to provide technical assistance for this purpose. SEC. 9. BILATERAL INVESTMENT TREATY. SEC. 9. The President should seek a bilateral investment treaty with UNTAET and the National Council of East Timor to enhance the legal framework for US investment in East Timor. SEC. 10. Scholarships for East Timorese students. SEC. 10. Scholarships for East Timorese students. The Secretary of State is authorized to provide scholarships and support for East Timorese students interested in studying in the US. $1,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2002 and 2003 for this program. SEC. 11. Plan for diplomatic facilities in East Timor. The Secretary of State is tasked with developing a detailed plan for establishing a US diplomatic mission in East Timor, including opening a fully functioning mission upon East Timor's independence and ensuring accreditation. A report must be submitted to the Committee on International Relations within three months of the enactment of the Act. The Secretary of State must submit a detailed plan for establishing a US diplomatic mission in East Timor, including the official opening of a facility in Dili, personnel requirements, estimated costs, and security needs. Subsequent reports on the plan's implementation must be submitted every six months until January 1, 2004. The report must detail revisions to the plan, including timetable, costs, and requirements. Reports can be submitted in classified or unclassified form. SEC. 12. SECURITY ASSISTANCE FOR EAST TIMOR. Authorization for the President to transfer excess defense articles and provide military education and training to East Timor once certification is provided that East Timor has established an independent armed forces and the assistance is in the national security interests of the United States. The President will conduct a study to determine the extent to which East Timor's security needs can be met by transferring excess defense articles, the impact of international military education and training assistance on the professionalism of East Timor's armed forces, and the terms and conditions for such assistance. The President will submit a report to relevant committees on the findings of a study regarding the provision of defense articles or training to East Timor. The Broadcasting Board of Governors is tasked with increasing the use of radio broadcasting to East Timor to ensure it serves as a reliable source of news. Additionally, a reporting requirement is in place regarding the provision of defense articles or training to East Timor. The Secretary of State, along with various other agencies, must provide biannual reports to Congress on developments in East Timor's political and economic situation. The biannual reports to Congress must include developments in East Timor's political and economic situation, evaluations of elections, refugee reintegration, a 3-year plan for US foreign assistance, expenditure details, and activities by the International Bank for Reconstruction. The biannual reports to Congress must include an assessment of US trade and investment relations with East Timor, including activities supported by various US trade agencies and negotiations with UNTAET or East Timor to facilitate their operation in the country. The biannual reports to Congress must include an assessment of US trade and investment relations with East Timor, cultural exchanges, Peace Corps activities, and a study on local agriculture with recommendations for technical assistance from the United States.
